message.content: This question requires basic knowledge about genetics and the inheritance of traits. When both a dominant and recessive gene are present, the dominant gene will be visible or expressed. This means that the dominant feature or trait associated with the dominant gene will be observable in the individual. Option (A) is incorrect because society is not directly related to gene expression. Option (C) is too broad and not specific to gene expression. Option (D) is unrelated to genetics and gene expression.

This question is related to the concept of dominant and recessive genes in genetics. When both a dominant and recessive gene are present, the dominant gene will be visible or expressed in the individual. Option (A) is incorrect as it is unrelated to genetics. Option (C) is incorrect because a person is not solely determined by a single gene. Option (D) is incorrect as "path" is not related to genetics.

This question requires an understanding of genetics and inheritance patterns. When both a dominant and recessive gene are present, the dominant gene will determine the visible feature or trait. Option (A) is incorrect because society is not a genetic trait. Option (C) is incorrect because it implies that only a person can have visible traits, while in reality, animals and plants also have visible traits. Option (D) is incorrect because it is not related to genetics or visible traits.

In the presence of both a dominant and recessive gene, the dominant gene will be visible or expressed. This means that the feature associated with the dominant gene will be displayed in the person. Option (A) is incorrect because society is not directly related to the expression of genes. Option (C) is incorrect because a person is the individual who carries the genes, not the visible result. Option (D) is unrelated to genetics as it refers to a path.
